user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskRegister_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_TaskRegister_Impl(osal_id_t global_task_id)
{
    int32                    return_code;
    OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t arg;
    int                      old_state;
    int                      old_type;

    /*
     * Set cancel state=ENABLED, type=DEFERRED
     * This should be the default for new threads, but
     * setting explicitly to be sure that a pthread_join()
     * will work as expected in case this thread is deleted.
     */
    pthread_setcancelstate(PTHREAD_CANCEL_ENABLE, &old_state);
    pthread_setcanceltype(PTHREAD_CANCEL_DEFERRED, &old_type);

    memset(&arg, 0, sizeof(arg));

    /* cppcheck-suppress unreadVariable // intentional use of other union member */
    arg.id = global_task_id;

    return_code = pthread_setspecific(POSIX_GlobalVars.ThreadKey, arg.opaque_arg);
    if (return_code == 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else
    {
        OS_DEBUG("OS_TaskRegister_Impl failed during pthread_setspecific() error=%s\n", strerror(return_code));
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TaskRegister_Impl:
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I searched the provided function and related definitions for any use of memcmp or any memory-comparison of C strings. There are no calls to memcmp, nor any other explicit memory-comparison operations on null-terminated strings (no strcmp/strncmp/memcmp usage). The code uses memset to zero a local union, pthread_setcancelstate/ pthread_setcanceltype/ pthread_setspecific, and strerror only to format an error message — strerror returns a char* but is not compared with memcmp. The macros provided (OS_DEBUG, OS_SUCCESS, OS_ERROR) do not introduce any memcmp usage. Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14, so nothing needs to be flagged for investigation with respect to that rule.
